title: Recently , I have received a summons from Unifund letting me know about an lawsuit they are filing against me . What do I do ?
question: I am scared and do not know what to do. I have other debt collectors trying to collect as well and have mounting student loans to pay off as well. How do I respond to their summons and would a bankruptcy attorney be my best option or should I hire a debt settlement attorney to help me negotiate? I have paid off one collector but have 3 more to answer to. In total my unsecured debt to around $12,000. Any advice would be much appreciate.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Credit,Debt,Debt settlement,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Summons and complaint,Sued for debt,Default judgment
answers:
Without having a complete picture regarding your income, liabilities and assets (as well as your age, occupation, and other factors), it is not possible to give you competent advice regarding bankruptcy versus debt settlement.

If you are served with a Summons and Complaint, you should first record the date and manner in which you were served, and then retain a lawyer to file a timely response on your behalf. In most instances, for Superior Court lawsuits, you have 30 days from the date of personal service to respond to the Summons and Complaint.

In the event you absolutely cannot afford an attorney to defend you, you can represent yourself "in pro per". You would file either an Answer or a General Denial, and pay the first appearance filing fee.

The form for the Answer is (Judicial Council Form PLD-C-010):

http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/pldc010.pdf

The form for the General Denial is (Judicial Council Form PLD-050):

http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/pld050.pdf

The filing fee depends upon the amount of the claim. If you cannot afford the first appearance filing fee, you may apply for a fee waiver. See:

http://www.courts.ca.gov/selfhelp-lowcosthelp.htm#fees

An Answer to Complaint typically includes a general denial plus a number of affirmative defenses.

The various affirmative defenses must be separately stated and must refer to the causes of action to which they relate in a manner by which they may be intelligently distinguished.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 431.30(g).)

Typical affirmative defenses for a breach of contract lawsuit include:

1. The complaint fails to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.

2. Plaintiff lacks standing to sue.

3. Plaintiff failed to mitigate any purported damages it may have suffered.

4. Plaintiff's claims, in whole or in part, are barred by the doctrine of laches.

5. Plaintiff's claims are barred by the equitable principle of unclean hands by virtue of Plaintiff's conduct and actions.

6. Plaintiff's claims are barred by the equitable principle of estoppel.

7. Plaintiff’s claims are barred by the statute of limitations set forth under Code of Civil Procedure sections 337(1) and 339(1).

If you have no money and no assets file a Chapter 7. If you have non-exempt assets you want to keep or if you have "disposeable income" that can fund a Ch 13 plan file a Ch 13. File a bankruptcy to get the creditors off your back and stop the lawsuits. Make sure to meet with a quaified bankruptcy attorney before you do anything. Most will meet with you for free.

As the others have said, bankruptcy is one option you may wish to consider. However, $12,000 is a relatively small amount of debt for discharging (meaning, essentially, a chapter 7 bankruptcy may only be filed and receive a discharge once every 8 years...and will remain on your credit report for up to 10 years; oftentimes people filing bankruptcy do so when an unforeseen hardship occurs, such as a medical emergency, or large dollar amount (over $20,000) lawsuit, etc.)

Still, there is no minimum amount of debt required before filing bankruptcy - ultimately, that choice exists with you and you alone.

Bottom line: you may wish to at answer /defend the lawsuit and see what happens to Unifund's case against you (an attorney here has given you great information how to begin that process, and another attorney offered valuable information about Unifund that appears hopeful to defending against the lawsuit). If defending the lawsuit doesn't work, or doesn't work for you for some reason, contact a bankruptcy lawyer to review your options.

Best of luck!

Michael Salanick, Esq.
msalanick@salanickkaw.com
www.salanicklaw.com

Bankruptcy is one option. Defending the lawsuit is another option. Unifund is a "debt buyer." When it sues, it expects that 90% of the time it will get a default judgment. If you make them prove their case, you will probably win because Unifund usually has a hard time getting witnesses from the original creditor to come to court to testify that you owe the underlying debt. Also, many of Unifund's accounts are past the Statute of Limitations.

You should consult a BK attorney and also a collection defense attorney. Stay away from "Debt Settlement", as those schemes are usually rip offs and do not stop a lawsuit.

Your first stop should be with a bankruptcy attorney. They will be able to advise you regarding the lawsuit and your possible need for a bankruptcy or debt settlement. As has been stated you have 30 days from the date you were served to answer the law suit. If you meet with an attorney and decide to file a bankruptcy you my be able to achieve that without the hassle and expense of responding to the lawsuit. You must however, consult with an attorney immediately.

My colleague is correct. Without having a picture of your financial situation, there is no real way to determine the better course of action for you. If you truly think bankruptcy is your only viable option, then consult with a bankruptcy attorney.
